title: General
stimulusHtml:
1 point maximum

Dactyl—Spondee—Dactyl—Dactyl—Dactyl—Spondee

  • The line must be completely correct in its scansion. Copying of the Latin need not be perfect. The final foot can be rendered as a spondee or as long-short or as long-anceps.

  • The student may put long and short marks over the Latin syllables or write out the names of each metrical unit as below.

  • If the student offers both styles of scansion and they do not match up, then the long and short marks take precedence over the writing out of the words “dactyl” and “spondee.”

  • Note the elision in the fourth foot as students often miss this (but students need not specifically mark the elision to get credit).
descriptions:
Student response earns none of the available points.

1 point maximum

Dactyl—Spondee—Dactyl—Dactyl—Dactyl—Spondee

  • The line must be completely correct in its scansion. Copying of the Latin need not be perfect. The final foot can be rendered as a spondee or as long-short or as long-anceps.

  • The student may put long and short marks over the Latin syllables or write out the names of each metrical unit as below.

  • If the student offers both styles of scansion and they do not match up, then the long and short marks take precedence over the writing out of the words “dactyl” and “spondee.”

  • Note the elision in the fourth foot as students often miss this (but students need not specifically mark the elision to get credit).

Student response earns one of the available points.

1 point maximum

Dactyl—Spondee—Dactyl—Dactyl—Dactyl—Spondee

  • The line must be completely correct in its scansion. Copying of the Latin need not be perfect. The final foot can be rendered as a spondee or as long-short or as long-anceps.

  • The student may put long and short marks over the Latin syllables or write out the names of each metrical unit as below.

  • If the student offers both styles of scansion and they do not match up, then the long and short marks take precedence over the writing out of the words “dactyl” and “spondee.”

  • Note the elision in the fourth foot as students often miss this (but students need not specifically mark the elision to get credit).
